Anyway! Funny story I meant to mention last week. He and his CEO took more than £1m in bonuses out of the business post the float and didn't tell shareholders.

BE11:23am

Neither did they tell their broker.

BE11:23am

Their broker having said previously that shareholders probably's taking more than £1m in bonuses for a float would probably not play that well.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

So they did anyway. They just didn't tell anyone.

BE11:23am

Honesty. This is what happened. Look:

BE11:24am

Oxford, UK; 04 October 2019: Sensyne Health plc (LSE: SENS), the British clinical AI technology company, announces that in December 2018 Lord Drayson, CEO, and Lorrie Headley, CFO, were awarded and paid post IPO bonuses of £850,000 and £200,000, respectively (the "Payments").
While the Company received a preliminary view from Peel Hunt LLP ("Peel Hunt"), the Company's nominated adviser and broker, as to a likely unfavourable market reaction to the proposed Payments, the Company did not discuss the proposals further with Peel Hunt prior to making the Payments. Peel Hunt was recently made aware, during the preparation of the Company's annual report, that the Payments had been made in December 2018 and has advised the Company that they constituted related party transactions that required notification at the time under Rule 13 of the AIM Rules for Companies. The Directors (other than Lord Drayson and Lorrie Headley) considered the Payments to be appropriate and remain of that view. Peel Hunt cannot advise as to whether the Payments were fair and reasonable.
The Company intends to consult with its major institutional shareholders on the Payments and its remuneration policy following the publication of its annual report on 7 October 2019.

Kiwi-juice Norges Bank statement (Hikvision owner): “Respect for human rights is a natural part of good business practice and risk management.” Still holders

VV75 ahh woodford again, the reverse midas
BE11:26am

Now, it wouldn't be a huge surprise if Peel Hunt were feeling a wee bit offside here. What with a cash-burning medtech secretly giving its C-suite more than £1m against its advice.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

In that context, wonder why Liberum's chosen to start coverage?

BE11:26am

Here's its bit about the payments.

BE11:27am

We understand investors’ frustration with these payments given their magnitude and the lack of transparency around them. However following extensive discussions with management and the board we believe the following:
1. Lack of transparency was a communications error: We understand that Sensyne had requested an opinion as to whether or not these payments were required to be disclosed but did not receive such opinion and hence assumed they were not. This is naive in our view but we do not believe that either the board or management attempted to hide the payments.
2. Changes will be made to ensure this does not happen again: The company has stated that it will take all necessary steps to prevent such an error happening again and more importantly will extensively discuss remuneration with shareholders to ensure that their expectations of payment levels are reflected in practice going forwards.
Ultimately the quantum of these payments is for the company’s remuneration committee to decide. But it is fair to say that many believe the board have made an error and that the magnitude of these cash bonuses was too great given the business remains a cash burning entity and management should have been sufficiently incentivised via stock holdings/options. We expect the board to engage to a much greater extent going forwards and that their views will be instrumental in driving future compensation policy. This incident has been a lesson for management and the board and we have received multiple reassurances that it will not be repeated. Given the quality and reputational standing of the people involved in the board, we believe the benefit of the doubt should be given.

A. M. @BE: (1.) sounds somewhat iffy.

BE11:29am

Sensyne uses its AI (created in partnership with Oxford
University) to analyse a vast pool of NHS data (the best
healthcare data globally in our view). This allows it to
provide services to improve pharma R&D/discover new
drug targets as well as create cost saving apps for
hospitals. The industry is taking note with Bayer signing a
£5m deal in June and a Fortune 200 health/tech player
signing another major deal recently. This isn’t surprising
given just one successful 6 week project could facilitate
FDA approval a year earlier than normal, driving $250m of
value for pharma. Sensyne's EV is just £86m. BUY.

BE11:37am

Q3 19 adjusted EBITDA of €383m In its trading update, Mondi reported Q3 19 adjusted EBITDA of €383m, which was 3% below our expectation of €393m (no consensus available). According to the company, like-for-like sales volumes were marginally lower y-o-y driven by industrial bags and uncoated fine papers, partly balanced by growth in corrugated packaging.
Guides Q4 19 EBITDA slightly lower
Selling prices in Q4 are guided to be marginally lower sequentially and, if sustained, this impact is expected to be largely offset by easing cost pressure and cost takeouts, signalling somewhat lower EBITDA. The company took downtime to manage inventory levels in sack kraft papers, and over the past six weeks order books for industrial bags have improved, which we find encouraging and suggests price declines seen in Q3 will likely be enough. Containerboard pricing has stabilised and the knock-on effect on corrugated board has been surprisingly small, while fine paper price pressure has not been that profound. All in, things are unlikely to get much worse, we believe.

A. M. @wayneJ: you have a point re BE's solitude on the left.
11:37 am
BE11:37am

2019E-20E EBITDA down by 2% and 6%
Mainly reflecting moderated volumes assumptions, lower pulp prices and more modest gains from investments, we reduce our 2019E-20E EBITDA estimates by 2% and 6%, respectively. We now assume 2019E EBITDA of €1.64bn (Reuters consensus €1.69bn, UBS 3% below), leading to a decline of 7% y-o-y, and 2020E EBITDA of €1.56bn (Reuters consensus €1.67bn, UBS 7% below), reflecting a further 5% decline. While we still believe 2020E will be supported by some volumes growth, incremental benefits from growth investments as well as modest cost inflation/cost takeouts/less maintenance, the impact of lower pricing should take its toll (assuming no recovery), and we would expect market estimates to drift downwards.
Valuation: price target lowered to 1,850p (2,000p)
Driven by estimate revisions, we lower our target price to 1,850p (previously 2,000p).
With key markets soon likely to trough, and with the share underperforming core peers by c20 p.p. year-to-date, we maintain our 12-month Buy rating. Despite the short-term headwinds, we think Mondi remains well positioned longer term with its low-cost asset base and growth investments supporting margins and returns.

BE11:38am

The sharp fall in Mondi’s Q3 profits appears to be related to its
kraft and uncoated fine paper grades. This should come as little
surprise to investors. The good growth in corrugated volumes,
combined with stable containerboard prices, gives cause for
optimism in the packaging sector. Full year consensus forecasts
now appear optimistic given the implied Q4 EBITDA. The stock
has significantly underperformed the sector year-to-date and so
may already have discounted this weaker outcome.

3Q EBITDA declined -9% QoQ to €383m (2Q: €423m) a -5% miss vs limited €405m cons. With 4Q outlook implying modestly lower QoQ EBITDA, we trim 2019 EBITDA c1%, but expect investor focus to be on 2020 earnings where we lower EBITDA c7% to €1,560m given softer macro/pricing. Our PT declines -7% to £19.00 (from £20.50). While Mondi likely to open lower, given recent under performance, we expect to see valuation support & would Buy on weakness.

Fox Full year EPS for Mondi?
BE11:39am

As Mondi entered 4Q, prices were on avg marginally lower vs 3Q.
However, they noted that if sustained, "the impact of lower pricing is expected to be largely offset by an easing of pressure on the cost base, supported by our ongoing profit improvement initiatives." To us this implies modestly lower QoQ EBITDA. Based on €1,680m Bloomberg EBITDA 2019 cons (9M19: €1,277m), the 4Q is at €403m (3Q: €383m) and assuming modestly lower QoQ EBITDA in 4Q vs 3Q, we see approx c2% (or €30m) cons downgrades (Jeff: €1,650m).
Expect Focus on 2020 forecasts: Into 2020, we expect benefits of lower maintenance costs (c€40m), capex projects (c€40m) & profit improvement initiatives to be more than offset by impact of lower avg pricing in key pulp & paper grades and lower FV forest gains. Our €1,560m 2020 EBITDA, is higher than the annualized 2H19: €756m which does not include the lower maintenance & higher capex benefits
What's Changed? We lower 2019 EBITDA c1% to €1,650m and 2020 EBITDA c7% to €1,560m (-6% vs €1,662m cons) driven by softer macro & lower avg prices for key pulp & paper grades. PT declines c7% in-line with EBITDA to £19.00 (from £20.50).

BE11:48am

We move to a N rating on Aston Martin (previously OW) following a greater than 2 month restriction. We have a cautious view on the business environment, given the weak demand outlook, upcoming Brexit deadline, pressure on cash flow/need for financing and lack of catalysts till 2H2020. Demand from the UK and Europe is unlikely to improve and 3 GT models have to pull all the weight, as the company ramps-up key new models. From there on, a lot depends on the success of the DBX, Valkyrie and the mid-engine cars. We think AML needs to sell ~9k cars to generate cash and equity value. For 2019, we forecast revenues of ~£1.05bn and an adj. Ebit margin of 6.3% (8% below company collected consensus of £73m). We resume coverage with a Neutral rating and a Dec-20 PT of £5.7 based on a peer correlated 2020E EV/Sales multiple valuation

BE11:50am

Step down in wholesale and GT mix a concern for an equity story
hinging on operating leverage: In July, Aston Martin cut its FY 2019
delivery guidance from 7.1-7.3k units to 6.3-6.5k units (vs. new JPMe
of ~6k in 2019). This implies a big cut, keeping in mind that we had
6.44k unit deliveries (incl. specials) in 2018 and that 2019 was the first
full sales year for the 2 new GT cars, Vantage (launched April'18) and
DBS Superleggera (launched 4Q18). We take a cautious view on
volumes going forward.
 Step-up in profitability in 2020: 2019 margins are affected by lower
volumes on core cars, unfavorable mix, unusually low volumes of
specials and low fixed cost absorption. Into 2020, we expect some
margin improvement from operating leverage (DBX), high value
specials and heritage models and reversal of impairment expense.

BE11:58am

As per Morgan Stanley:

BE11:58am

Flows and revenue beat: Q1 10 (June year-end) flows of £1.7bn is ahead of MSe expectations of £1.1bn and £1.3bn in Q1 19 driven backbook acquisitions of £0.9bn. AUM of £101.8bn is 1% ahead of MSe and +2.5% vs June-19 while revenues of £128.1m is 7% ahead of MSe and +6% yoy suggested limited signs of blended margin pressure feeding through given higher cash AUM (higher margin 70-80bps). We expect the share price to react positively on the back of these results. Though still see risks to revenue margins building as we look forward from a combination of flow headwinds in HL Multi-manager range, growing competition (eg. stockbroking, ISAs) and rate environment. Flow outlook cautious: While headline flows of £1.7bn is strongly ahead of our forecast and ~7% annualised rate, this includes £0.9bn of acquisitions from JPM and Baillie Gifford (~3.5% annualised flow rate ex these). Management caution that flows in Q2 will be impacted by weak investor sentiment around Brexit, political uncertainty and global macro, but marketing spend will likely decrease to offset this though still in line with client growth.

BE11:59am

HL has announced Q1 AuA of £101.8bn against consensus of £101.4bn, which generated revenue of £128.1m (6% growth) against consensus of £127.9m, with net inflows in the seasonally quiet Q1 of £1.7bn against consensus of £1.58bn. HL attracted 35,000 new customers in the quarter and it commented that it had experienced 'weak investor sentiment arising from continuing Brexit and political uncertainty in the UK and wider global macro issues such as trade tariffs.' The Q1 numbers are consistent with our current forecasts, as are HL's comments regarding client caution. Consequently, we are not changing our forecasts, which we marked to market very recently. We are, however, upgrading our recommendation to Add from Hold following the recent, and in our opinion unwarranted, share price weakness.

BE12:07pm

Philips just released an ad hoc stating that Q3 profits fell c7% short of consensus adjusted EBITA for the quarter. It provided refreshed views for 2019, and now assumes only modest full-year margin progression of 10-20bp (c2% downgrades) and expects to revert to c100bp margin improvement thereafter (c2% downgrade to 2020).
● Revenues in line: Revenues for the quarter grew 6% at constant exchange rates (CER) to EUR4.7bn – in line with our EUR4.68bn forecast (up 5.8% CER). Comparable order intake growth in the quarter is expected to be flat on the back of strong 11% growth in the third quarter of 2018.
● EBITA softer than expected: Group EBITA margins contracted 80bp in Q3 to 12.4%, or 100bp shy of us and consensus. This was largely caused by continued soft Connected Care margins which slipped 450bp yoy to an 11.3% adjusted EBITA margin (we were looking for 14.8% for the quarter). This was said to be due to US/China tariffs and delays of mitigating actions which led to too low inventory.
● Management outlook: Management now expect 10-20bp full-year EBITA margin expansion (ie 13.2% to 13.3% for FY 2019). Consensus is at 13.4%, so this implies a c2% downgrade for the full year. The company expects to return to 100bp margin expansion in 2020, which seems to be an admission that it will now not achieve its 15% margin aspiration for 2020. Consensus is at 14.4%, while we are at 14.6% 2020 margin, so this implies a further c2% downgrades.
● Comment: While it is good to see growth coming through and Philips has a good track record of margin expansion over the past few years, Q3 is a slip-up and Connected Care remains the perennial underperformer. If revised guidance is delivered, the downgrades to 2019 and 2020 will be quite modest – but shares will likely be down (perhaps by over 5%),
reflecting the likely shortfall of the company’s original 2020 goals and lowered confidence in its ability to execute. The problems in Connected Care seem solvable but seem to us to require some organisational or structural changes. The shortfall may be offset by projected margin expansion over the next mid-term planning period – new mid-term targets will be set in H1 2020.
